Class MazeTraversal

  • java.lang.Object
    • MazeTraversal

  • public class MazeTraversal
extends java.lang.Object
    MazeTraversal is a class that represents the recursive solution to navigating from "Start" to "Finish" through a 12x12 character array. When constructed and given a maze, it finds it's entry point within MazeTraversal(char[][], int) and then begins it's recursive calls to navMaze(char[][], int, int). It also utilizes printMaze(char[][]) and clearScreen() to clear the terminal and print the current maze, with an intentional delay in-between to simulate animation. The class also holds it's initial and final maze for reference if needed.
    Author:
    Ben Mitchinson
    See Also:
    MazeTraversal(char[][], int), navMaze(char[][], int, int), printMaze(char[][]), clearScreen()

    • Constructor Detail

      • MazeTraversal

        public MazeTraversal(char[][] mazeToNav,
                     int speed)
        The constructor for MazeTraversal finds the entry point to the given 12x12 character array "mazeToNav". It then waits 6 seconds for the sake of presentation, and begins the first recursive call to navMaze(char[][], int, int). It utilizes printMaze(char[][]) to show the initial maze given before progress begins.
        Parameters:
        mazeToNav - 12x12 Maze to navigate
        speed - Time to delay between printing screens.
        See Also:
        MazeTraversal, printMaze(char[][]), navMaze(char[][], int, int)

    • Method Detail

      • navMaze

        private boolean navMaze(char[][] maze,
                        int xLoc,
                        int yLoc)
        The navMaze method is used recursively to "move" through a 12x12 character maze. It checks the characters in each "direction" from the perspective of xLoc and yLoc. If a possible move is detected (meaning a '.' is found), navMaze is called recursively, moving the character in that direction.

        It's base case is the scenario in which no moves are possible, or it has ended up at the right most column, thus finding the end. From there, the next search of direction is called

        It uses printMaze(char[][]) and clearScreen() to print it's continuous progress through the maze.

        Parameters:
        maze - The maze to navigate, possibly marked by an X with previous progress
        xLoc - The current location of navigation in the x direction
        yLoc - The current location of navigation in the y direction
        Returns:
        true if a move is possible, false if not.
        See Also:
        printMaze(char[][]), clearScreen()

      • printMaze

        private void printMaze(char[][] maze)
        Prints the given maze (12x12 character array) with proper spacing.
        Parameters:
        maze - A 12x12 character array
        See Also:
        printMaze(char[][])

      • clearScreen

        private void clearScreen()
        Prints 50 blank lines to clear the screen of the terminal. Some call it annoying, I call it genius.
        See Also:
        MazeTraversal
